feed.title: Google Trends and Stocks Relationship - Data Analysis Project

entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll sumarize your finding for the class presentation.

The class presentation will use this notebook in slide mode, as I do during lecture time.

You'll need to download the following zip file, unzip it, and run the following notebook install-support.ipynb to install the slide capabilities.

The notebook notebook-slideshow-example.ipynb will give you examples on how to use slides within the iPython notebook.

You should also write this notebook so that you can convert it nicely into a pdf document using the commands

ipython nbconvert NB4_report.pynb --to latex
pdflatex NB4_report.tex

See here for further references on how to do that.

In this notebook, you'll

  • describe your problem as stated in the propectus

  • comment on your data sources, on their format, on the difficulties to get them

  • present the main challenge you encountered

  • present your finding in the form of expresive graphics

Be sure to include an introduction section motivating your visualizations, with a description of the substantive context and why it is interesting.

Cite the source of the data and any other references that you used in carrying out your project.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.
In [2]: 
%load_ext rmagic

Problem

Our group will examine the relationship between Google Trends (Google web search data) and stock prices of large companies namely in the S&P500.

First, we will determine if there is a correlation between search data for the company name/ticker (“Apple” or “AAPL”) and the stock price.

Second, we will determine if there is a correlation between search data for positive terms related to the company name/ticker (“Buy AAPL”) and the stock price.

Third, we will determine if there is a correlation between search data for negative terms related to the company name/ticker (“Sell AAPL”) and the stock price.

Finally, we will use this information to see if we can make a simple trading algorithm based on trends in the Google search data and see how a hypothetical portfolio would function on historical data.

Data Sources

We used Google Trends and Yahoo Finance as our sources of data.

Google Trends data will be obtained from the Google Trends website (http://www.google.com/trends/explore#cmpt=q). Although there is a “Download as CSV” option, we will need to find a way to find Google search data for a large number of search terms for a large number of stocks. One problem was that the Google trends data (how much it is searched) is normalized to a scale from 0-100 for every search. That means some of the values are 0, which we had to adjust for when we were cleaning the data. The Google Trends data was a csv, which made it easy to understand, but the hard part was getting all the data we needed.

Therefore, we will need to create a script that can quickly repeat the process, or use an API that has already done so (http://techslides.com/hacking-the-google-trends-api/).

Stock data is obtained from Yahoo Finance by creating a script or using a script available.

Luke Cleans

After finally getting all the data he needs, Luke needs to see what data he is working with. He randomly opens up a couple of files to get a general sense of the data he has gathered.

In [3]: 
%%R
testing = read.csv("./data/raw/DowJones/3M Company_gtrends.csv")
testing2 = read.csv("./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/V_gtrends.csv")
testing3 = read.csv("./data/raw/SP500/sell BEN_gtrends.csv")

print(head(testing))
print(head(testing2))
print(head(testing3))

        Date X3M.Company Price
1 2004-01-09           0    NA
2 2004-01-16           0    NA
3 2004-01-23         100    NA
4 2004-01-30           0    NA
5 2004-02-06           0 79.81
6 2004-02-13           0 79.68
        Date  V Price
1 2004-01-09 35    NA
2 2004-01-16 35    NA
3 2004-01-23 35    NA
4 2004-01-30 35    NA
5 2004-02-06 34    NA
6 2004-02-13 35    NA
        Date  V Price
1 2004-01-09 35    NA
2 2004-01-16 35    NA
3 2004-01-23 35    NA
4 2004-01-30 35    NA
5 2004-02-06 34    NA
6 2004-02-13 35    NA

Oh no! A lot of the things

Main Challenges

The most difficult part of the project was determining the correlation between two time series (Google Trends data and stock data). We have no experience in calculating this value and may need some guidance.

Another cause of difficulty will be creating a trading algorithm for a hypothetical stock portfolio backtest. However, this part of the project will be out of personal interest. The goal is not to create a profitable stock trading algorithm, but to help us understand the relationship between Google Trends data and stock price data better.

It is hard to draw a solid conclusion from this. Even if there is a strong correlation, we did not know whether the changing stock prices affected the google trends data or it was the other way around. It is unclear which caused what.

Visualization

Our first graph shows the density of the correlations

In [3]: 
from IPython.core.display import Image 
Image(filename='visualizations/test.png')
Out[3]:

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll perform the actual analysis of the data stored in the directory

./data/cleaned

If the data is not ready yet (e.g. the other members of the team in charge of cleaning the data are not done yet), you may want to simulate cleaned data in the form you want them to be in order to perform the analysis. This may also help you data cleaning team to come up with the rigth data frame. If you choose to do so, store your simulated data into the directory

./data/simulated

Having performed analysis of simulated data may help you with the analysis of the actual data, since you will be able to notice deviations between the real and simulated data, which may be worth explaining and investigating further.

The graphics your going to produce as a result of your analysis should be store in the directory:

./visualization

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

Our Plan¶

In [1]: 
%load_ext rmagic
In [92]: 
%%R
##creating a list of files in the folder
list_of_files <- list.files("~/Desktop/googletrends-stocks/notebooks/data/raw/DowJones_Modified")
normal_cor_list <- c()
percent_cor_list <- c()
my_str = "data/raw/DowJones_Modified/"

##creating a function to gather all the data

get_all_data = function(x) {
    if (x == 'SP500') {
        my_str = 'data/raw/SP500/'
        list_of_files <<- list.files("~/Desktop/googletrends-stocks/notebooks/data/raw/SP500")
    }
    for (s in 1:length(list_of_files)){
        ##opening each file in the folder
        myStock = read.csv(paste(my_str,list_of_files[s],sep = ""))
        myStock = na.omit(myStock)
        growth2 = c(0)
        growth = 0
        ##adding a column with relative stock prices
        for (i in 1:length(myStock$Price)){
            growth = (myStock$Price[i]-myStock$Price[i-1])/myStock$Price[i-1]*100
            growth2= c(growth2,growth)
        }
        ##getting rid of key term files, so only normal files remain
        if (substr(list_of_files[s],1,4) == "sell"){
            next
        }
        if (substr(list_of_files[s],1,3) == "buy"){
            next
        }
        if (toupper(substr(list_of_files[s],2,2)) == (substr(list_of_files[s],2,2))) {
            next
        }
        ##intermediate data cleaning step which should be unnecessary after cleaning is linked
        if (nrow(myStock) == 0){
            next
        }
        if (ncol(myStock) < 3){
            next
        }
        myStockNew = data.frame(myStock, "PriceGrowth"= growth2)
        ##lists of correlatons for absolute and relative stock price data
        normal_cor_list <<-c(cor(myStockNew[,2], myStockNew[,3]),normal_cor_list)
        percent_cor_list <<-c(cor(myStockNew[,2], myStockNew[,4]),percent_cor_list)
        normal_cor_list <<- na.omit(normal_cor_list)
        percent_cor_list <<- na.omit(percent_cor_list)
        }
        return()
}

get_all_data('DowJones_Modified')

print(normal_cor_list)    


#hist(normal_cor_list, breaks = 20, col = "red")
#plot(density(normal_cor_list))
#print(length(normal_cor_list))

[11] -0.170361859  0.921798143 -0.237335886 -0.170731436  0.639339138
[16]  0.115637367  0.669745522 -0.320027255 -0.048845710 -0.313069667

[26] -0.082504011

%%R
# set up some fake test data
time <- seq(0,72,12)
betagal.abs <- c(0.05,0.18,0.25,0.31,0.32,0.34,0.35)
cell.density <- c(0,1000,2000,3000,4000,5000,6000)

#add extra space to right margin of plot within frame
par(mar=c(5, 4, 4, 4) + 0.1)

# Plot first set of data and draw its axis
plot(time, betagal.abs, pch=16, axes=F, ylim=c(0,1), xlab="", ylab="", 
type="b",col="black", main="Mike's test data")
axis(2, ylim=c(0,1),col="black")
mtext("Beta Gal Absorbance",side=2,line=2.5)
box()

# Allow a second plot on the same graph
par(new=T)

# Plot the second plot and put axis scale on right
plot(time, cell.density, pch=15,  xlab="", ylab="", ylim=c(0,7000), axes=F, 
type="b", col="red")
mtext("Cell Density",side=4,col="red",line=2.5)
axis(4, ylim=c(0,7000), col="red",col.axis="red")

# Draw the time axis
axis(1,pretty(range(time),10))
mtext("Time (Hours)",side=1,col="black",line=2.5)

# Add Legend
legend(5,7000,legend=c("Beta Gal","Cell 
Density"),text.col=c("black","red"),pch=c(16,15),col=c("black","red"))

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
#Google Trends & Stock Prices: Data Cleaning

We will clean up the data in "./data/raw" by removing rows that have missing values. First, we will clean the data for the Dow Jones companies, and then clean the data for the SP500 companies and Dow Jones companies.

Preliminary Setup

Step #0: Contributors

  • Jordeen Chang: Wrote data cleaning notebook

Step #1: Identify the problem

In [11]: 
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic

Let us first take a look at the data that we are dealing with. For each file, we have three columns, one for the date, the other for how popular the search term was (gathered from Google Trends), and the price of the stock during that time (gathered from Yahoo).

In [31]: 
%%R
testing = read.csv("./data/raw/DowJones/3M Company_gtrends.csv")
testing2 = read.csv("./data/raw/DowJones/CAT_gtrends.csv")

print(head(testing))

        Date X3M.Company Price
1 2004-01-09           0    NA
2 2004-01-16           0    NA
3 2004-01-23         100    NA
4 2004-01-30           0    NA
5 2004-02-06           0 79.81
6 2004-02-13           0 79.68
In [33]: 
%%R
print(lapply(testing, class))

$Date
[1] "factor"

$X3M.Company
[1] "integer"

$Price
[1] "numeric"

Looking at this we can see that we have 0 for our google trends values and NA for some of the prices. There is no point in using data points that do not have prices or have 0 for the google trends values because it will mess up the analysis. We also want to standardize all the data, so we will make sure everything follows the same format. We will have the first column be of class "Date", the second column be "integer", and the third be "numeric." Now we know what data points we need to remove and we can get on to cleaning!

Data Cleaning Code

Step #2: A function that cleans the data given the file name

Now we will write a function that takes in a filename from the folder "./data/raw/DowJones_Modified" and

  • converts the csv file into a data frame.

  • checks the format of the columns and changes them if they are not (Date, integer, numeric).

  • checks to see if any of the values are NA or 0. If so, the function will remove that row.

  • saves this cleaned data frame into a csv file of the same name under the directory "./data/cleaned/DowJones_Modified".

In [12]: 
%%R
cleanDow = function(fileName) {
    stock = read.csv(paste("./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/", fileName, sep = ""))
    modes = data.frame(lapply(stock, class))
    if (modes[1] != "Date") {
        stock[,1] = as.Date(stock[,1], '%Y-%m-%d')
    }
    if (modes[2] != "integer") {
        stock[,2] = as.integer(as.character(stock[,2]))
    }
    if (modes[3] != "numeric") {
        stock[,3] = as.numeric(as.character(stock[,3]))
    }
    col = colnames(stock)
    stock = stock[!is.na(stock[,1]) & !is.na(stock[,2]) & !is.na(stock[,3]) & stock[,2] != 0,]
    write.csv(stock, file = paste("./data/cleaned/DowJones_Modified/", fileName, sep = ""), row.names = FALSE)
}

Step #3: Apply the function to all files in DowJones directory

Now we will run this function on a list of files in the directory "./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/" and it will clean all the files in this directory.

In [13]: 
%%R
allDow = list.files("./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/")
lapply(allDow, cleanDow)

Let's print some of this out so we can see whether or not the data is cleaned correctly. We will use the same file that we saw earlier.

In [35]: 
%%R
testing = read.csv("./data/cleaned/DowJones/3M Company_gtrends.csv")
print(head(testing))

        Date X3M.Company Price
1 2004-04-02          84 81.78
2 2004-04-16          90 83.73
3 2004-04-23          93 87.90
4 2004-04-30          62 86.48
5 2004-05-07          66 84.43
6 2004-05-14          70 83.81

Perfect. The data is cleaned and our function works. Let's try to clean the rest of our data.

Step #4: Repeat for SP500 companies

Now we will repeat the process for the SP500 companies.

In [14]: 
%%R
cleanSP = function(fileName) {
    stock = read.csv(paste("./data/raw/SP500/", fileName, sep = ""))
    modes = data.frame(lapply(stock, class))
    if (modes[1] != "Date") {
        stock[,1] = as.Date(stock[,1], '%Y-%m-%d')
    }
    if (modes[2] != "integer") {
        stock[,2] = as.integer(as.character(stock[,2]))
    }
    if (modes[3] != "numeric") {
        stock[,3] = as.numeric(as.character(stock[,3]))
    }
    col = colnames(stock)
    stock = stock[!is.na(stock[,1]) & !is.na(stock[,2]) & !is.na(stock[,3]) & stock[,2] != 0,]
    write.csv(stock, file = paste("./data/cleaned/SP500/", fileName, sep = ""), row.names = FALSE)
}
In [15]: 
%%R
allSP = list.files("./data/raw/SP500/")
lapply(allSP, cleanSP)

Step #5: Repeat for Dow Jones (Unmodified)

And we repeat for the unmodified Dow Jones.

In [17]: 
%%R
cleanDowUnmodified = function(fileName) {
    stock = read.csv(paste("./data/raw/DowJones/", fileName, sep = ""))
    modes = data.frame(lapply(stock, class))
    if (modes[1] != "Date") {
        stock[,1] = as.Date(stock[,1], '%Y-%m-%d')
    }
    if (modes[2] != "integer") {
        stock[,2] = as.integer(as.character(stock[,2]))
    }
    if (modes[3] != "numeric") {
        stock[,3] = as.numeric(as.character(stock[,3]))
    }
    col = colnames(stock)
    stock = stock[!is.na(stock[,1]) & !is.na(stock[,2]) & !is.na(stock[,3]) & stock[,2] != 0,]
    write.csv(stock, file = paste("./data/cleaned/DowJones/", fileName, sep = ""), row.names = FALSE)
}
In []: 
%%R
allDowUnmodified = list.files("./data/raw/DowJones/")
lapply(allDowUnmodified, cleanDowUnmodified)

Another comparison of the data before cleaning and the data after.

In [21]: 
%%R
print(head(read.csv("./data/raw/DowJones/3M Company_gtrends.csv")))
print(head(read.csv("./data/cleaned/DowJones/3M Company_gtrends.csv")))

[1] "3M Company_gtrends.csv"              
[2] "American Express Company_gtrends.csv"
[3] "AT&T, Inc._gtrends.csv"              
[4] "AXP_gtrends.csv"                     
[5] "BA_gtrends.csv"                      
[6] "buy BA_gtrends.csv"                  
        Date X3M.Company Price
1 2004-01-09           0    NA
2 2004-01-16           0    NA
3 2004-01-23         100    NA
4 2004-01-30           0    NA
5 2004-02-06           0 79.81
6 2004-02-13           0 79.68
        Date X3M.Company Price
1 2004-04-02          84 81.78
2 2004-04-16          90 83.73
3 2004-04-23          93 87.90
4 2004-04-30          62 86.48
5 2004-05-07          66 84.43
6 2004-05-14          70 83.81

Now all our files in "./data/cleaned/" are formatted correctly and ready to be analyzed!

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
#Google Trends & Stock Prices: Data Gathering

We will create a python script "data_gathering.py" that aggregates two types of data:

  1. Google Trends values from Google Trends
  2. Stock prices from Yahoo Finance API

Our goal is to find a relationship between the Google Trends values and the stock prices for the companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, a list of 30 top U.S. companies, and the S&P500, a list of 500 top U.S. companies. The end product of the data gathering script should be many different csv files with three columns: "Date", "Google Trends Value", and "Stock Price" for different search terms related to each company. Excited? Great, then let's begin!

Preliminary Setup

Step #0: Contributors

  • Anshuman Dewangan: Researched all sources for data gathering. Wrote all data gathering code. Authored data gathering ipython notebook. Outlined procedure for other steps of the project.

Step #1: Creating the Directory Structure

First, let's set up the directory structure we'll need for our project. We'll create three folders in our current directory: script, data, and visualizations. Inside data, we'll create three more directories: raw, cleaned, and simulated.

In [1]: 
%%bash
# Makes the directories and displays the contents of the current directory
mkdir ./script ./data ./data/raw ./data/cleaned ./data/simulated ./visualizations
ls -r

visualizations
script
README.md
NB4_project_report.ipynb
NB3_data_analysis.ipynb
NB2_data_cleaning.ipynb
NB1_data_gathering.ipynb
desktop.ini
data


mkdir: cannot create directory ‘./script’: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ‘./data’: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ‘./data/raw’: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ‘./data/simulated’: File exists
mkdir: cannot create directory ‘./visualizations’: File exists

Step #2: Installing Necessary Modules

Some modules need to be installed using the pip installer before we begin. Run the code below to make sure you have everything you have everything you need to execute the following steps successfully.

In [6]: 
%%bash
sudo pip install mechanize

Downloading/unpacking mechanize
  Running setup.py egg_info for package mechanize
    
Installing collected packages: mechanize
  Running setup.py install for mechanize
    
Successfully installed mechanize
Cleaning up...

Data Gathering Code

Step #3: Module Import

Now that we got all the boring stuff out of the way, it's time to write our actual data gather script! As a first step in our code, let's make all the necessary imports that we will need to use. We'll see how each import is being used later on. If you run this cell and get an error, return to the previous step and make sure you installed "mechanize" correctly.

In [7]: 
# Imports all important modules for the program
import sys
import datetime
import pandas
import csv
import cookielib
import mechanize
import re
from StringIO import StringIO

Step #4: Load Dow Jones Data

Next, let's load the file "DowJones_Modified.csv" into a pandas dataframe called "stocks". "DowJones_Modified.csv" is a manually created file of the list of companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average from Yahoo Finance with two columns: "Company", "Ticker". However, we modified the company names to incorporate more popular search terms. For example, we would use "American Express" instead of "American Express Company" to get more search results.

Source: http://finance.yahoo.com/q/cp?s=%5EDJI

In [8]: 
# Reads "DowJones_Modified.csv" of stocks and ticker symbols into a pandas dataframe
stocks = pandas.read_csv('./data/DowJones_Modified.csv')
companies = stocks.Company
tickers = stocks.Ticker

print stocks[0:6]

            Company Ticker
0  American Express    AXP
1            Boeing     BA
2       Caterpillar    CAT
3             Cisco   CSCO
4           Chevron    CVX
5           du Pont     DD

[6 rows x 2 columns]

Step #5: Create Queries Lists

Now we will create a list of lists with all the queries we want to search on Google Trends. We want to pull data for six different queries for each company:

  1. Company name
  2. Ticker symbol
  3. "Buy" + ticker symbol
  4. "Sell" + ticker symbol
  5. "Buy" + company name
  6. "Sell" + company name

For example, Apple will have six different queries:

  1. Apple
  2. AAPL
  3. Buy AAPL
  4. Sell AAPL
  5. Buy Apple
  6. Sell Apple

We'll create a class that takes in different types of queries for each company. The input will be the following arguments: "company", "ticker", "'buy ' + ticker", "'sell ' + ticker", "'buy ' + company", "'sell ' + company". The output will be a list of lists with all the search terms we want.

In [9]: 
# Creates a list of lists with search terms for all companies in the format given by inputs
def query(*arg):
    queries = []
    for query in arg:
        queries.append([query[n] for n in range(0, len(stocks))])
    return queries
        
queries = query(companies, tickers, "buy " + tickers, "sell " + tickers, "buy " + companies, "sell " + companies)
print queries

[['American Express', 'Boeing', 'Caterpillar', 'Cisco', 'Chevron', 'du Pont', 'Disney', 'General Electric', 'Goldman Sachs', 'Home Depot', 'IBM', 'Intel', 'Johnson & Johnson', 'JPMorgan Chase', 'Coca-Cola', "McDonald's", '3M', 'Merck', 'Microsoft', 'Nike', 'Pfizer', 'Procter & Gamble', 'AT&T', 'Travelers', 'UnitedHealth', 'United Technologies', 'Visa', 'Verizon', 'WalMart', 'Exxon Mobil'], ['AXP', 'BA', 'CAT', 'CSCO', 'CVX', 'DD', 'DIS', 'GE', 'GS', 'HD', 'IBM', 'INTC', 'JNJ', 'JPM', 'KO', 'MCD', 'MMM', 'MRK', 'MSFT', 'NKE', 'PFE', 'PG', 'T', 'TRV', 'UNH', 'UTX', 'V', 'VZ', 'WMT', 'XOM'], ['buy AXP', 'buy BA', 'buy CAT', 'buy CSCO', 'buy CVX', 'buy DD', 'buy DIS', 'buy GE', 'buy GS', 'buy HD', 'buy IBM', 'buy INTC', 'buy JNJ', 'buy JPM', 'buy KO', 'buy MCD', 'buy MMM', 'buy MRK', 'buy MSFT', 'buy NKE', 'buy PFE', 'buy PG', 'buy T', 'buy TRV', 'buy UNH', 'buy UTX', 'buy V', 'buy VZ', 'buy WMT', 'buy XOM'], ['sell AXP', 'sell BA', 'sell CAT', 'sell CSCO', 'sell CVX', 'sell DD', 'sell DIS', 'sell GE', 'sell GS', 'sell HD', 'sell IBM', 'sell INTC', 'sell JNJ', 'sell JPM', 'sell KO', 'sell MCD', 'sell MMM', 'sell MRK', 'sell MSFT', 'sell NKE', 'sell PFE', 'sell PG', 'sell T', 'sell TRV', 'sell UNH', 'sell UTX', 'sell V', 'sell VZ', 'sell WMT', 'sell XOM'], ['buy American Express', 'buy Boeing', 'buy Caterpillar', 'buy Cisco', 'buy Chevron', 'buy du Pont', 'buy Disney', 'buy General Electric', 'buy Goldman Sachs', 'buy Home Depot', 'buy IBM', 'buy Intel', 'buy Johnson & Johnson', 'buy JPMorgan Chase', 'buy Coca-Cola', "buy McDonald's", 'buy 3M', 'buy Merck', 'buy Microsoft', 'buy Nike', 'buy Pfizer', 'buy Procter & Gamble', 'buy AT&T', 'buy Travelers', 'buy UnitedHealth', 'buy United Technologies', 'buy Visa', 'buy Verizon', 'buy WalMart', 'buy Exxon Mobil'], ['sell American Express', 'sell Boeing', 'sell Caterpillar', 'sell Cisco', 'sell Chevron', 'sell du Pont', 'sell Disney', 'sell General Electric', 'sell Goldman Sachs', 'sell Home Depot', 'sell IBM', 'sell Intel', 'sell Johnson & Johnson', 'sell JPMorgan Chase', 'sell Coca-Cola', "sell McDonald's", 'sell 3M', 'sell Merck', 'sell Microsoft', 'sell Nike', 'sell Pfizer', 'sell Procter & Gamble', Step #6: Setup Browser

Cool, we now have all the search terms we want to get data for from Google Trends. Before we can actually pull the data from Google Trends, however, we run into two problems:

  1. The data is not directly downloadable from a csv url
  2. The data is only securely available to Google users

These problems arise because Google Trends has no API that allows users to pull data easily, making our lives harder. Therefore, we have create a virtual browser that would allow us to pull csv files directly by authenticating Google using login credentials. Otherwise, there is no direct way to download the csv data through programming code. For ideas on how to do this, we conducted a lot of research and got some major help from our source below.

Source: https://gist.github.com/tlmaloney/5650699

In [10]: 
# Open browser
br = mechanize.Browser()

# Make it seem like we are an actual person
br.set_handle_robots(False)

# Create cookie jar
cj = cookielib.LWPCookieJar()
br.set_cookiejar(cj)

# Act like we're a real browser
br.addheaders = [('User-agent', 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.9.0.1) Gecko/2008071615 Fedora/3.0.1-1.fc9 Firefox/3.0.1')]

# Login in to Google
response = br.open('https://accounts.google.com/ServiceLogin?hl=en&continue=https://www.google.com/')
forms = mechanize.ParseResponse(response)
form = forms[0]
form['Email'] = "DherintoR"
form['Passwd'] = "forthestars"
response = br.open(form.click())

Step #7: Get Google Trends Data

That should do it! Now we are ready to get Google Trends data for our first query: "American Express". First, we'll put our queries relateed to the company, which are often more than one word, into a form the browser will understand: with "%20" between each word. Then, we will append the search to our Google Trends url to get a csv of the Google Trends data.

Source: http://www.google.com/trends/explore

In [11]: 
# Split queries list into a format that can be entered into the url       
query_split = queries[0][0].split()
query_params = '%20'.join(query_split)

# Get CSV from Google Trends   
response = br.open('http://www.google.com/trends/trendsReport?hl=en-US&q=' + query_params + '&cmpt=q&content=1&export=1') 
reader = csv.reader(StringIO(response.read()))

# Print first 10 lines of csv file
print queries[0][0]
for x in range(0,10):
    print reader.next()

Step #8: Clean the Data

It worked! Interesting, the csv file comes with a lot of junk information. Additionally, the actual Google Trends data comes in an awkward format: "Date (given as a weekly range), "Google Trends Value". Let's clean the data so that it only saves the date for the Friday of each week and puts all the information into two different lists: "dates" and "values".

Source: https://support.google.com/trends/answer/4365533?hl=en&ref_topic=4365599

In [12]: 
# Reload the page
response = br.open('http://www.google.com/trends/trendsReport?hl=en-US&q=' + query_params + '&cmpt=q&content=1&export=1') 
reader = csv.reader(StringIO(response.read()))

# Create empty lists to be populated with date and trend values
dates = []
values = []

# Populate lists with dates and Google Trends values in the correct formate.
for row in reader:
    # Looks for the right rows to get data from, ignoring the junk
    try:
        date, value = row
    except ValueError:
        continue
    # Takes the date for the Friday of the week and puts it in the correct format
    if re.search('[0-9]{4}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{2}', date):
        dates.append(str((datetime.datetime.strptime(date[-10:], "%Y-%m-%d")-datetime.timedelta(days=1)).strftime("%Y-%m-%d"))) # Uses last date in time period
        values.append(value)

#Print the contents of the list
print dates[0:6]
print values[0:6]

['2004-01-09', '2004-01-16', '2004-01-23', '2004-01-30', '2004-02-06', '2004-02-13']
['72', '72', '68', '65', '67', '68']

Step #9: Explanation of Google Trends Data

Let's take a moment's break from writing code to explain how the Google Trends data works.

How Trends Data is Normalized

The Google Trends data for any particular query is normalized on a scale of 0-100, with "100" being the day that received the highest search volume. According to the Google Trends help page, "Normalized means that sets of search data are divided by a common variable, like total searches, to cancel out the variable's effect on the data."

Data that is Excluded

Google is very protective over its search data, which is why it does not provide the original data but normalized values. Additionally, Google Trends does not provide information for the following data:

  1. "Searches made by few people: Trends only analyzes data for popular search terms, so terms with low volume won’t appear."
  2. "Duplicate searches: Trends eliminates repeated queries from a certain user over a short period of time."

Problems with Google Trends Data

With this information about Google Trends Data in mind, we run into three large problems.

  1. Data is only available weekly (for high volume search terms only) or monthly (for all other search terms) starting from January 2004 when Google began. This limits the number of data points we have access to. See Example #1.
  2. We cannot pull data for "unpopular" search terms. This limits the search terms that are effective for many of our companies. For example, while "American Express" retrieves data (as shown above), "sell CSCO" returns a csv with blank data. We will avoid pulling data for these queries in our final data gathering script. See Example #2.
  3. Since the data is normalized, any time period with significantly less searches compared to other months will return a "0". Since the search volume grows over time, a lot of the data in the early years (2004-2007) just has zeroes for values. We will remove these data points during data cleaning. See Example #3.

Due to these unavoidable biases, we take our conclusions with a grain of salt. However, these problems should not get in the way of finding the general relationship between search data and stock price, so let's push forward!

In [42]: 
#Example #1: Only Monthly Google Trends Data

query_params = '%20'.join(query_split)
response = br.open('http://www.google.com/trends/trendsReport?hl=en-US&q=' + query_params + '&cmpt=q&content=1&export=1') 
reader = csv.reader(StringIO(response.read()))
print "Example #1: Only Monthly Google Trends Data\n"

for x in range(0,10):
    print reader.next()

reader = csv.reader(StringIO(response.read()))
print "Example #2: Unavailable Google Trends Data\n"

print "\nEnd of csv file"

print "Example #3: Limited Google Trends Data\n"

print "-"*50 + "\n"

Step #10: Get Stock Data

Great! We have two lists for our query "American Express", one with the dates and one with the corresponding Google Trends values. Now, let's try getting stock data on the ticker symbol for American Express (AXP) using the Yahoo Finance API. We'll load a csv with daily stock price data for American Express (AXP) from January 1, 2004 (when Google Trends data begins) to present.

Source: https://code.google.com/p/yahoo-finance-managed/wiki/csvHistQuotesDownload

In [39]:

# Opens the Yahoo Finance csv file

reader1 = csv.reader(StringIO(response1.read()))

# Print first 6 lines of csv file

for x in range(0,6):

Step #11: Add Prices

Next, we'll save the closing prices of the stock data in a dictionary called "prices_dict". Then, we will use this dictionary to add prices to the list "prices" for the corresponding date in "dates". If no price is found for a specific date, we will enter ""; these values will be removed later during data cleaning.

In [40]: 
# Reloads the csv file
response1 = br.open(base_url + dt_url)
reader1 = csv.reader(StringIO(response1.read()))

# Creates a dictionary that maps dates to closing prices for that day
prices_dict = {row[0]: row[4] for row in reader1}

# Adds stock prices to the corresponding dates found in the Google Trends data
prices = []
for date in dates:
    # Tries to add the price for the date from the Google Trends data
    try:
        prices.append(prices_dict[date])
    # Adds a blank value if the price is not available for the Google Trends date
    except:
        prices.append("")
        
# Print the contents of "prices" list
print prices[0:20]

['', '', '', '', '53.06', '53.65', '53.16', '53.42', '52.77', '52.12', '51.08', '50.03', '52.43', '', '50.58', '50.27', '48.95', '48.49', '48.86', '49.63']

Step #12: Write the csv file

Fantastic! Now we have three lists with corresponding data:

  1. dates - Dates
  2. values - Google Trends values
  3. prices - Stock prices

What's important to note is that the Google Trends value in "values[0]" and the stock price in "prices[0]" corresponds to the date in "dates[0]". This fact is crucial when executing the last step, which is to write a csv file containing all these values in separate columns: "Date", "Value" (header is denoted by the query term), and "Price". The csv file will be saved as "American Express_gtrends.csv" in the directory "data/raw/DowJones_Modified".

In [43]: 
# Sets the filename as the query
filename = queries[0][0]
filename.replace(" ", "")

# Creates a file and writes values from our three lists
if dates != []: # Confirms that Google Trends data exists before creating the csv file
    with open("./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/" + filename + "_gtrends.csv", 'w') as file:
        writer = csv.writer(file, lineterminator = '\n')
        # Writes a header row with the titles: Date, Query, Price
        writer.writerow(['Date', queries[0][0], "Price"])
        # Writes a row for each value of date, value, and price
        for row in zip(dates, values, prices):
            writer.writerow(row)
        # Closes and saves the file
        file.close()
else:
    print "Failed to get data for " + queries[x][n]
    
# View contents of csv file
with open("./data/raw/DowJones_Modified/" + filename + "_gtrends.csv", 'r') as file:
    for x in range(0,10):
        print file.next()

Final Script: data_gathering.py

Awesome! As you can see, we have the Google Trends data and stock data side-by-side for "American Express". Now we can write a full script "data_gathering.py" that automates the process for all search queries. The result is many different csv files created for each query. These csv files can easily be read into R dataframes, as seen in the data cleaning step.

In [44]: 
%%file script/data_gathering.py

"""
Downloads Google Trends and stock data for search terms related to companies in the Dow Jones Index. 

Creates a csv file with "Date", "Google Trends value", and "Price" for each search term.

Files will be saved in the "../data/raw/Data_Modified" directory.

Make sure to run "sudo pip install mechanize" before running the code for the first time.

Data Sources: Google Trends (www.google.com/trends). Yahoo Finance (www.finance.yahoo.com).
"""


# Imports all important modules for the program
import sys
import datetime
import pandas
import csv
import cookielib
import mechanize
import re
from StringIO import StringIO
 
    
# Reads "DowJones_Modified.csv" of stocks and ticker symbols into a pandas dataframe
def stocks_data(data='../data/DowJones_Modified.csv'):
    stocks = pandas.read_csv(data)
    company = stocks.Company
    ticker = stocks.Ticker
    return stocks, company, ticker
stocks, companies, tickers = stocks_data()


# Creates a list of lists with search terms for all companies in the format given by inputs
def query(*arg):
    queries = []
    for query in arg:
        queries.append([query[n] for n in range(0, len(stocks))])
    return queries       
queries = query(companies, tickers, "buy " + tickers, "sell " + tickers, "buy " + companies, "sell " + companies)


# Sets up a virtual browser to download Google Trends and stock data
br = mechanize.Browser()
def browser_setup():
    # Open browser
    br.set_handle_robots(False)
    
    # Create cookie jar
    cj = cookielib.LWPCookieJar()
    br.set_cookiejar(cj)
    
    # Act like we're a real browser
    br.addheaders = [('User-agent', 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.9.0.1) Gecko/2008071615 Fedora/3.0.1-1.fc9 Firefox/3.0.1')]
    
    # Login in to Google
    response = br.open('https://accounts.google.com/ServiceLogin?hl=en&continue=https://www.google.com/')
    forms = mechanize.ParseResponse(response)
    form = forms[0]
    form['Email'] = "DherintoR"
    form['Passwd'] = "forthestars"
    response = br.open(form.click())
browser_setup()


# Pulls Yahoo Finance stock data for given ticker from 2004-present
def yahoo_finance(ticker_symbol):
    base_url = "http://ichart.yahoo.com/table.csv?s="
    dt_url = '%s&a=%s&b=%s&c=%s&d=%s&e=%s&f=%s&g=d&ignore=.csv'% (ticker_symbol, "01", "01", "2004", "00", "00", "0000")
    return base_url + dt_url

    
# Create CSV for each stock in stocks list
for n in range(0,len(companies)):
    
    # Get stock data for the stock
    url = yahoo_finance(tickers[n])
    # Opens the Yahoo Finance csv file
    response1 = br.open(url)
    reader1 = csv.reader(StringIO(response1.read()))
    # Creates a dictionary that maps dates to closing prices for that day
    prices_dict = {row[0]: row[4] for row in reader1}

    for x in range(0,len(queries)):
        
        # Split queries list into a format that can be entered into the url                
        query_split = queries[x][n].split()
        query_params = '%20'.join(query_split)
        
        # Get CSV from Google Trends
        response = br.open('http://www.google.com/trends/trendsReport?hl=en-US&q=' + query_params + '&cmpt=q&content=1&export=1') 
        reader = csv.reader(StringIO(response.read()))
        
        # Creates empty lists to be populated with data
        dates = []
        values = []
        prices = []
        
        # Populate lists with dates and Google Trends values in the correct formate.
        for row in reader:
            # Looks for the right rows to get data from, ignoring the junk
            try:
                date, value = row
            except ValueError:
                continue
            # Takes the date for the Friday of the week and puts it in the correct format
            if re.search('[0-9]{4}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{2}', date):
                dates.append(str((datetime.datetime.strptime(date[-10:], "%Y-%m-%d")-datetime.timedelta(days=1)).strftime("%Y-%m-%d"))) # Uses last date in time period
                values.append(value)
        
        # Adds stock prices to the corresponding dates found in the Google Trends data
        for date in dates:
            # Tries to add the price for the date from the Google Trends data
            try:
                prices.append(prices_dict[date])
            # Adds a blank value if the price is not available for the Google Trends date
            except:
                prices.append("")

        # Sets the filename as the query
        filename = queries[x][n]
        filename.replace(" ", "")
        
        # Creates a file in "data/raw/DowJones_Modified/" and writes values from our three lists
        if dates != []:
            with open("../data/raw/DowJones_Modified/" + filename + "_gtrends.csv", 'w') as file:
                writer = csv.writer(file, lineterminator = '\n')
                # Writes a header row with the titles: Date, Query, Price
                writer.writerow(['Date', queries[x][n], "Price"])
                # Writes a row for each value of date, value, and price
                for row in zip(dates, values, prices):
                    writer.writerow(row)
                # Closes and saves the file
                file.close()
        else:
            print "Failed to get data for " + queries[x][n]

Overwriting script/data_gathering.py
